pr_title: [RW-2840][risk=low] Support delegated user credentials without private keys

timeline.message: Get integration tests into working shape.
Simplify some of the integration test config and remove unused WorkbenchEnvironment.
Create a DelegatedUserCredentials class and migrate all usage away from GCS-stored keys.
Bring back GCS-stored key code and add feature flag to toggle between key and keyless usage.
Tweak things a bit so DirectoryService is only instantiated from within a request context; this fixes the local API smoke tests.
Remove unintended Gradle build file change.
Revert a couple unintended rebase errors.
Add a couple test comments and remove an unnecessary instance var.

timeline.bodyText: This seems high to me. I think 5 minutes might be more typical for this kind of token. Do we have a use case where we'd need a long-lived token here? (and if it expires, the refresh should kick in - right?)
timeline.author: calbach

replies.bodyText:
AFAICT, 60min appears to be Google's default expiration for oauth2 access tokens if left blank (c.f. https://cloud.google.com/iam/docs/reference/credentials/rest/v1/projects.serviceAccounts/generateAccessToken#request-body and https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13851157/oauth2-and-google-api-access-token-expiration-time).
Another clue comes from logic in the base OAuth2Credentials class, which refreshes a token if the expiration time is any less than 5 minutes away: https://github.com/googleapis/google-auth-library-java/blob/master/oauth2_http/java/com/google/auth/oauth2/OAuth2Credentials.java#L58. So requesting an expiration of 5 minutes would effectively mean we can never reuse an access token. (That said, to be fair I think most services are regenerating delegated credentials for each inbound request anyway, so we're likely not yet using the benefit of cached access tokens.)
I don't disagree that an hour feels like more than we "need", but given that it seems to be pretty widely used, I'm inclined to leave as-is.
replies.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText:
The documentation for this client indicates that it should be closed: https://github.com/googleapis/java-iamcredentials/blob/master/google-cloud-iamcredentials/src/main/java/com/google/cloud/iam/credentials/v1/IamCredentialsClient.java#L56-L57
Providing this as a spring singleton and moving this to be a constructor parameter (callers would inject the client and pass it through) would probably be my preferred solution to this.
timeline.author: calbach

replies.bodyText: Good point – I'd been trying to avoid getting too deep into changing our Spring dependencies, but the combination of the .close() method and the awkwardness of logic to lazily create default instances forced me to take a stab at a full dependency-injected approach. It's cleaner in this class, but I still get a bad feeling when dealing with our service-level Spring DI (especially in tests). I tried to clean things up a bit, including adding autowiring to one of our test classes (to reduce the churn when we add new dependencies) and fixing an awful bit of Spring config leakage between our unit and integration tests (see the change to build.gradle – that one really had me surprised).
